text.p: This is how major world bond markets were trading in late European business on Thursday.

GERMANY - German debt traded sideways at higher levels in late afternoon, as the market appeared to catch its breath after setting yet another record in early morning trading. The March Bund future on the London International Financial Futures and Options Exchange (LIFFE) was trading at 103.18, up 0.08 from Wednesday's settlement price.

BRITAIN - British gilts pared losses late in Thursday's session but still settled 6/32 lower on the day as political worries conspired with disappointment over higher- than-expected inflation data. The March long gilt future on LIFFE was trading at 113-10/32, down 06/32 from Wednesday's settlement price.

FRANCE - French bond futures closed higher but off their highs in low volume as investors turned cautious about the notionnel's ability to push much higher. The March notional bond future on the MATIF in Paris settled at 131.90, up 0.16 from Wednesday's settlement price.

ITALY - Italian debt markets undermined by uncertainty over likelihood of early steps to rein in budget deficit, future dropped through key support, dealers say volumes was fading. Poorer than expected interest at Btp auctions also gave sharp tug to rug under markets' feet. The March bond future on LIFFE was trading at 130.44, down 0.58 from Wednesday's settlement price.

UNITED STATES - U.S. government securities prices were firmer at midday Thursday as dealers prepared for Treasury's auction of $10 billion of 30-year bonds. The March Treasury bond future on the Chicago Board of Trade was trading at 112-23/32, up 10/32 from Wednesday's settlement price. The long bond was quoted to yield 6.69 percent.

JAPAN - The key March Japanese government bond (JGB) futures contract ended the Tokyo session higher but well off its intraday high. In after hours trading the March future on LIFFE was trading at 126.35, up 0.34 from Wednesday's settlement price on the Tokyo Stock Exchange.

EUROBONDS - The primary market saw a braod range of deals in both the floating and fixed-rate sectors. U.S. food trading and processing company Cargill launched a $200 million three-year bond to yield 12 basis points over U.S. Treasury notes. The borrower is rated Aa3 by Moody's Investors Service and AA- by Standard & Poor's Corp.
